title: Parables of Stewardship and Judgment
shortSummary: Luke 16 presents Jesus’ teachings on wise stewardship, faithfulness, and the eternal consequences of earthly choices. It includes the parable of the unjust steward, instructions on serving God versus mammon, and the story of the rich man and Lazarus, emphasizing accountability and the reality of heaven and hell.
timeline: c. AD 30 - Ministry of Jesus in Galilee and Judea

keyCharacters.name: The Unjust Steward
keyCharacters.description: A manager accused of wasting his master's goods who cleverly secures his future by reducing debts owed to his master.

keyCharacters.name: The Rich Man
keyCharacters.description: A wealthy man who lives in luxury but ignores the poor beggar Lazarus at his gate, later suffering torment after death.

keyCharacters.name: Lazarus
keyCharacters.description: A poor beggar covered with sores who longs for crumbs from the rich man's table and is comforted after death in Abraham's bosom.

keyCharacters.name: Abraham
keyCharacters.description: The patriarch who appears in the afterlife scene, explaining the fixed gulf between the saved and the lost.

definitions.definition: A manager or servant entrusted with the care and administration of another’s property or affairs.
Wealth or riches, often personified as a master competing with God for a person's loyalty.
A term describing the place of comfort in the afterlife where the righteous dead awaited Christ’s coming.
A small stroke or mark in Hebrew writing; used here to emphasize the unchanging nature of God's law.

outline.heading: The Parable of the Unjust Steward
outline.description: Jesus tells of a steward accused of wasting his master's goods who shrewdly reduces debts to secure favor with others. The parable teaches the importance of wise use of worldly resources and foresight in spiritual matters.

outline.heading: Teachings on Faithfulness and Mammon
outline.description: Jesus instructs His disciples to be faithful in small things and warns against serving two masters, emphasizing that loyalty must be to God rather than wealth.

outline.heading: Jesus’ Rebuke of the Pharisees
outline.description: Jesus confronts the covetous Pharisees who mock Him, highlighting their self-righteousness and affirming the enduring authority of God's law.

outline.heading: Teaching on Divorce and Adultery
outline.description: A brief but firm statement on the sanctity of marriage, condemning divorce and remarriage as adultery.

outline.heading: The Rich Man and Lazarus
outline.description: Jesus contrasts the eternal destinies of a rich man who ignored a poor beggar and Lazarus who suffered in life but was comforted after death, teaching the reality of judgment and the sufficiency of Scripture for repentance.

application: Be faithful and wise in managing the resources God entrusts to you, using them to glorify Him and help others.
Serve God wholeheartedly, avoiding divided loyalties between Him and worldly wealth or possessions.
Recognize the eternal consequences of your earthly choices and live with an awareness of heaven and hell.
Trust and obey the Scriptures as the sufficient guide for repentance and salvation, rather than seeking miraculous signs.

keyVerses.text: No servant can serve two masters: for either he will hate the one, and love the other; or else he will hold to the one, and despise the other. Ye cannot serve God and mammon.
keyVerses.significance: This verse clearly teaches the impossibility of divided loyalty between God and wealth, calling believers to wholehearted devotion.

keyVerses.text: He that is faithful in that which is least is faithful also in much: and he that is unjust in the least is unjust also in much.
keyVerses.significance: It emphasizes the importance of faithfulness in small responsibilities as a test of character and readiness for greater trust.

keyVerses.text: There was a certain rich man, which was clothed in purple and fine linen, and fared sumptuously every day: And there was a certain beggar named Lazarus, which was laid at his gate, full of sores,
keyVerses.significance: These opening verses of the rich man and Lazarus parable set the stage for a powerful lesson on compassion, justice, and eternal destiny.

keyVerses.text: And he said unto him, If they hear not Moses and the prophets, neither will they be persuaded, though one rose from the dead.
keyVerses.significance: This verse underscores the sufficiency of Scripture for salvation and the hardness of heart that rejects God’s Word.
